claim: CASL Club sessions were designed to achieve these goals (Fig. 1).
title: Figure 1. Specific tools and skills were introduced during each session to help students achieve the three objectives of CASL Club.
caption: Workshop sessions were designed around the three objectives. Objective-specific tools were introduced and skills were practiced over the eight hour-long sessions.

claim: Some general tips for implementing a CASL Club based on our experiences are provided (Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: General tips for implementing a CASL Club.

claim: Additionally, eleven of twelve students self-identified as a scientist, and ten of twelve students self-identified as a researcher (Fig. 3A).
title: Figure 3. CASL Club students identified as scientists with self-reported confidence in general skills related to searching and analyzing scientific literature, which contrasted with the small number of students self-reporting regular reading of journal articles.
caption: Student responses to the statements (A) “I am a scientist,” “I am a researcher,” (B) “I can usually understand the main points of a scientific journal article” and “I am confident in my ability to find a scientific journal article online” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and (C) “I regularly read scientific journal articles” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and a post-survey administered at the end of the course were measured on a Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Horizontal bars indicate means, and error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.

claim: In accordance with this sense of scientific identity, the majority of the students expressed a high degree of confidence in general skills (“I can usually understand the main points of a scientific journal article” and “I am confident in my ability to find a scientific journal article online”, mean response of “agree” for each statement) (Fig. 3B).
title: Figure 3. CASL Club students identified as scientists with self-reported confidence in general skills related to searching and analyzing scientific literature, which contrasted with the small number of students self-reporting regular reading of journal articles.
caption: Student responses to the statements (A) “I am a scientist,” “I am a researcher,” (B) “I can usually understand the main points of a scientific journal article” and “I am confident in my ability to find a scientific journal article online” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and (C) “I regularly read scientific journal articles” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and a post-survey administered at the end of the course were measured on a Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Horizontal bars indicate means, and error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.

claim: Despite their previous research experience and high degree of confidence in general skills, seven of twelve indicated that they had never presented a critique of a scientific journal article, and only two of twelve agreed or strongly agreed with the statement “I regularly read scientific journal articles” (Fig. 3C).
title: Figure 3. CASL Club students identified as scientists with self-reported confidence in general skills related to searching and analyzing scientific literature, which contrasted with the small number of students self-reporting regular reading of journal articles.
caption: Student responses to the statements (A) “I am a scientist,” “I am a researcher,” (B) “I can usually understand the main points of a scientific journal article” and “I am confident in my ability to find a scientific journal article online” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and (C) “I regularly read scientific journal articles” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and a post-survey administered at the end of the course were measured on a Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Horizontal bars indicate means, and error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.

claim: The majority of the students sampled had taken more than three courses that included exposure to primary scientific literature (Fig. 5).
title: Figure 5. Variation in exposure to reading and/or discussion of scientific literature between two sampled student populations from two universities.
caption: The previous study sampled 33 students prior to beginning the journal club (Robertson, 2012). Our pre-course survey sample included 12 students.

claim: At our institution, a public, comprehensive, historically American Indian university, within a group of high achieving students who plan to attend medical or graduate school, the majority had not taken any classes that included reading and/or discussion of primary scientific literature (Fig. 5).
title: Figure 5. Variation in exposure to reading and/or discussion of scientific literature between two sampled student populations from two universities.
caption: The previous study sampled 33 students prior to beginning the journal club (Robertson, 2012). Our pre-course survey sample included 12 students.

claim: In contrast, the mean response to the statement “I regularly read scientific journal articles” increased significantly (Fig. 3C).
title: Figure 3. CASL Club students identified as scientists with self-reported confidence in general skills related to searching and analyzing scientific literature, which contrasted with the small number of students self-reporting regular reading of journal articles.
caption: Student responses to the statements (A) “I am a scientist,” “I am a researcher,” (B) “I can usually understand the main points of a scientific journal article” and “I am confident in my ability to find a scientific journal article online” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and (C) “I regularly read scientific journal articles” on a pre-survey administered prior to beginning the CASL Club and a post-survey administered at the end of the course were measured on a Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Horizontal bars indicate means, and error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.
